IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 9240 S1381-1169(14)00372-0 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.08.025 Elsevier B.V. Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for the Biginelli reaction. Effect of Mo loading K. Kouachi a ⁎ G. Lafaye b S. Pronier b L. Bennini c S. Menad c a Faculté des Sciences de la Nature et de la Vie, Département des Troncs Communs, Université de Bejaia, 06000, Algeria Faculté des Sciences de la Nature et de la Vie, Département des Troncs Communs, Université de Bejaia 06000 Algeria b IC2MP UMR 7285 CNRS, Université de Poitiers, 4 rue Michel Brunet, 86073 Poitiers Cedex 09, France IC2MP UMR 7285 CNRS, Université de Poitiers 4 rue Michel Brunet Poitiers Cedex 09 86073 France c Laboratoire LCAGC, Département de Chimie, Faculté des Sciences, Université M. Mammeri de Tizi-Ouzou, 15000, Algeria Laboratoire LCAGC, Département de Chimie, Faculté des Sciences, Université M. Mammeri de Tizi-Ouzou 15000 Algeria ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +213 771174230. Graphical abstract Alumina supported Mo catalysts with varying metal loading (2–12wt%) were tested in the Biginelli reaction under solvent free conditions for synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2-(1H)-one (DHPM). The DHPM yield increased with Mo loading, going through a maximum for 7wt% Mo. Alumina supported Mo catalysts appeared to be highly stable and reusable materials for this reaction. A suite of characterization techniques that included X-ray diffraction, Fast Fourier Transform analysis and FTIR of adsorbed pyridine revealed that the DHPM formation is related to the existence of Brønsted acid sites that would be linked to the presence of Al2(MoO4)3 phase. Keywords Molybdenum Supported catalysts Biginelli reaction Dihydropyrimidinones 1 Introduction The development of new reactions, capable of forming multiple connections, in a single step, with good overall yields, while respecting the environment, has become an important challenge for academic and industrial laboratories. The multicomponent reactions (MCRs) are fully in line with this context since they lead to atom and step economies. They are defined as the assembly process in a single step of at least three or more reactants that will participate in the structure of the final product [1–3]. One such MCRs is the Biginelli reaction, one of the most important reaction for generating the dihydropyrimidinones (DHPMs) with diverse medicinal applications [4]. DHPMs and their derivatives have in fact exhibited remarkable therapeutic and pharmacological activities as calcium channel blockers [5], antiviral, antibacterial, antitumor, antioxidant and anti-inflammatory [6–9]. The classical Biginelli procedure for the preparation of dihydropyrimidinones is through a one-pot cyclocondensation of aldehyde, β-ketoester, urea/thiourea under strong acidic conditions [10]. However, this protocol suffers from drawbacks such as long reaction times, high reaction temperatures, environmental pollution by using organic solvents and frequently low yields, especially in the case of some substituted heteroaromatic aldehydes [11]. In order to enhance the efficiency of Biginelli reaction, various Lewis and/or Brønsted acid catalysts have been studied such as PPh3 [12], ZrOCl2·8H2O [13], trifluoromethanesulfonic acid [14], Cu(NH2SO3)2 [15] and TaBr5 [16]. Furthermore, the use of heterogeneous catalysts has received a lot of attention for this transformation since it offers easy recovery and recycling of the catalytic material. For example, Fe3O4/PAA-SO3H [17], Sr(OTf)2 [18], ZnO [19], TiO2/CNT [20], H3PW12O40/SiO2 [21] and sulphated tin oxide (TSO) [22] revealed high selectivity toward DHPMs with a short reaction time and reusability of catalysts for several times. The goal of the present work was to evaluate the influence of molybdenum loading on the catalytic properties of Al2O3-supported Mo for the Biginelli reaction under solvent free conditions (Scheme 1 ). The catalysts were characterized by electron microscopy, Fast Fourier Transform analysis, X-ray diffraction and FTIR of adsorbed pyridine. These characterization results were further combined with catalytic data obtained for the Biginelli reaction, to derive conclusions regarding the structure-reactivity correlations for the Mo/γ-Al2O3 system. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The support was a γ-alumina with a specific surface area of 213m2 g−1. The support was calcined in flowing air at 500°C for 5h. Mo based catalysts with different metal loadings were prepared by wet impregnation of the γ-alumina support at room temperature using an aqueous solution of ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O). After impregnation, the catalysts were dried at 120°C for 48h and then calcined at 500°C (heating rate=2°Cmin−1) in air for 5h. The resulting catalysts are denoted in this manuscript as xMoAl, where x indicates the weight percentage of Mo. 2.2 Catalyst characterization All the characterizations were performed on previously calcined samples. The molybdenum content of the different catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, model optima 2000 DV) after digestion in an acid solution. The BET specific surface areas were measured by nitrogen adsorption–desorption at −196°C using a Micromeritics Tristar apparatus. The BJH method was used to determine the mean pore size. Prior to these physisorption measurements, the samples were degassed at 250°C for 5h. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were recorded on a Panalytical Empeyrean instrument, using Cu Kα radiation (λKα =0.1504nm) and scanning 2θ from 10° to 80° with a step of 0.05° and a time per step of 240s. Crystalline phases were identified by comparison with the Powder Diffraction Files (PDF) standards from the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database (ICSD). The morphology of the catalysts was studied by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) to determine the particle size over the alumina support. HRTEM measurements were carried out on a Jeol JEM 2100 UHR equipped with a LaB6 filament. The apparatus has a linear resolution of 0.14nm and is equipped with a Gatan Ultrascan CCD camera with a resolution of 2k ×2k. The phase composition and structure were obtained in the same electron microscope by microanalysis EDS and Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), respectively. Interreticular distances d hkl as well as lattice parameters were calculated from the distances between the spots and the angles formed by the lines passing through these spots. A program [23,24] allows one to check the calculated values by drawing the theoretical pattern along the same zone axis and by comparing it to the experimental pattern. Before analysis in the electron microscope, powder sample was dispersed in ethanol, and the solution dropped on a nickel grid previously covered with a holey carbon film. The surface acidity of the solids was investigated through Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of pyridine adsorption with an intention of obtaining a comparative evaluation of Lewis (L) and Brønsted (B) acid sites in the catalysts. Pyridine FTIR spectra were recorded on a Thermo Nicolet Nexus FTIR spectrometer. Samples were compacted into thin pellets and activated at 450°C under a secondary vacuum (10−6 mbar) overnight. After cooling until room temperature, pyridine adsorption was performed for 5min after pressure stabilization. The cell was then kept under a secondary vacuum for 1h. The thermo desorption of pyridine was carried out at 150°C for 30min. The IR spectra were recorded at room temperature in a spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector (Deuterium TriGlyceride Sulfur) and KBr beam splitter, with a resolution of 2cm−1 and 64scans. 2.3 Catalytic test The Biginelli reaction was chosen as a model reaction to test the catalytic activity of the xMoAl materials. The reaction was performed under solvent free conditions. In a 25mL single-neck round bottom flask with an air cooler, a mixture of benzaldehyde (2mmol), ethyl acetoacetate (2mmol), urea (3mmol) and xMoAl catalyst (0.2g) was stirred at 100°C for 1h. The reaction was monitored by thin layer chromatography (hexane/ethyl acetate: 6/4). After one-hour reaction time, the resulting solidified mixture containing the catalyst was cooled down to room temperature. Since DHPM is soluble in hot ethanol, the mixture was washed with boiling ethanol and then filtered to remove the catalyst. The filtrate was poured into crushed ice involving recrystallisation of a residue suspended in solution. The residue (containing DHPM) was then subsequently collected by filtration and once again recrystallized from hot ethanol to afford pure product. The isolated catalyst was dried at 100°C overnight and was reused in the next runs without further purification. DHPM was identified by comparing its melting point and analytical spectroscopic data (IR, 1H, 13C NMR) with those reported in literature [25–27]. Melting points were determined using an Electrothermal SMP 11. IR spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu FTIR-8400 spectrometer. NMR experiments were recorded with a Bruker Avance 400 spectrometer at 400MHz for 1H nuclei and at 100MHz for 13C nuclei. The chemical shifts are expressed in part per million (ppm) relative to TMS (δ =0ppm) and the coupling constant J in Hertz (Hz). NMR multiplicities are reported using the following abbreviations: br=broad, s=singulet, d=doublet, t=triplet, q=quadruplet, m=multiplet. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations 3.1.1 Physical properties The chemical analysis and textural properties of xMoAl catalysts after calcination are summarized in Table 1 . The weight loading of Mo was varied between 2 and 12wt%. The experimental Mo weight loading corresponds well to nominal loading. The specific surface area (S BET) values decrease progressively, as the molybdenum loading increases, from 213m2 g−1 for the bare support to 70m2 g−1 for 12MoAl. This behaviour agrees with literature [28–30]. A likely cause for this loss could be a partial blocking of the micropores of the γ-Al2O3 support by the crystallites of dispersed metal oxides, since the pore volume (V Pore) decreases with increasing Mo loading (Table 1). Solid state reactions leading to new phases may also be responsible for the diminishing surfaces areas. Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the γ-alumina support and xMoAl catalysts. The XRD patterns of the 2MoAl (Fig. 1b) and 5MoAl (Fig. 1c) catalysts did not differ from that of the γ-Al2O3 support (Fig. 1a) (2θ =37°, 43°, 46° and 67°). The absence of diffraction peaks associated to a molybdenum oxide phase suggests the high dispersion of the molybdenum containing species, which are very likely present as an amorphous phase or as too small crystallites to be detected by XRD analysis. Observation of 2MoAl and 5MoAl (Fig. 2 ) samples by electronic microscopy revealed a uniform distribution of nanoparticles over the alumina support. The phase composition and structure of these particles could not be determined by EDS and FFT, respectively, because of the small size of these particles (≈1nm) and the high crystallinity of γ-Al2O3. For the 7MoAl catalyst, additional peaks appear on the XRD pattern at 2θ =21.9°, 22.5° and 23.4° that correspond to Al2(MoO4)3 phase in β-orthorhombic structure (Fig. 1d). This result was confirmed by FFT (Fig. 3b) and EDS analysis (Fig. 3c). The Al2(MoO4)3 particles present a size in the range of 30–60nm (Fig. 3a). However, it is important to note that MoO3 has not been detected, neither by XRD, nor by FFT and EDS analysis. This observation is contrary to the observations of McMillan et al. [31] and Cheng et al. [32]. They have shown that the Al2(MoO4)3 phase is thermodynamically stable phase that forms at high MoO3 loading with calcinations temperatures above 600°C. This discrepancy may be related to the different γ-Al2O3 support and/or the different experimental conditions adopted during the preparation of samples. In fact, Okamoto et al. [33] have demonstrated that molybdena–alumina catalysts are very sensitive to preparation parameters, such as surface area of alumina, volume of the impregnation solution [34], drying process [35], pH of the impregnation solution and calcination conditions [36]. It should be noticed that Rajagopal et al. [28] have also reported the formation of Al2(MoO4)3 at relatively low loading of Mo on silica-aluminas and calcined at only 500–550°C. On the other hand, the presence of characteristic XRD peaks corresponding to orthorhombic phase of MoO3 (2θ =12.7°, 23.3°, 25.5°, 27.3°, 33.7° and 49.2°) was clearly observed for 9MoAl (Fig. 1e) and 12MoAl (Fig. 1f) catalysts. These two samples also present the Al2(MoO4)3 phase in β-orthorhombic structure. The narrow, sharp peaks obtained for 12MoAl indicate that this material presents large crystal sizes. FFT and EDS analysis of 9MoAl are in accordance with the XRD results and confirm the presence of Al2(MoO4)3 and MoO3 phases. Fig. 4b and c gives representative FFT results of Al2(MoO4)3 and MoO3 particles, respectively. The observation by electron microscopy of 9MoAl has shown that Al2(MoO4)3 was always in presence of MoO3 (Fig. 4a) while isolated MoO3 particles could also be found (Fig. 5 ). EDS revealed that most of the MoO3 particles that are in interaction Al2(MoO4)3 contain some Al, presumably incorporated into the MoO3 structure. The comparison between Figs. 4a and 5 clearly shows that Al2(MoO4) and MoO3 particles in interaction (40–120nm) are larger than that of isolated MoO3 (10–40nm). The opposite result was found for 12MoAl sample, which presents very large MoO3 particles (600nm and over) while the Al2(MoO4)3 particle size is in the 70–150nm range. These particles were too large to be analyzed by FFT but MoO3 phase was confirmed by EDS. Al2(MoO4)3 phase was clearly determined by FFT for 12MoAl. Nevertheless, for 30% of the analyzed particles, the interreticular distances d hkl present some deviations from the theoretical values. Moreover, the EDS analysis of these particles gives a heterogeneous distribution of atomic percentage of Mo, O and Al. It is then reasonable to assume that Al and Mo atoms were incorporated into the Al2(MoO4)3 structure, resulting in a Al x Mo y O z composition and a shift of the d hkl distances. It should be noted that the formation of the Al2(MoO4)3 phase can explain the specific surface area of the samples to decrease as well as the formation of large MoO3 crystallites at higher molybdenum loadings. Fig. 6 presents schematic views of the particles of Mo/γ-Al2O3 depending on the Mo content. The proposed representations are deduced from the above characterizations. 3.1.2 Acid surface properties The acidic properties of the materials were probed with pyridine adsorption followed by FTIR. This technique allows a clear distinction between Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. Due to the nitrogen electron lone pair, pyridine interacts with acidic centers in a specific way to form (i) the pyridinium ion on protonic sites (PyH+) and (ii) coordinated species on Lewis acid sites (PyL). Pyridine was adsorbed at room temperature and then thermally desorbed. Fig. 7 presents the IR spectra of the samples when pyridine is evacuated at 150°C. The 1617, 1489 and 1450cm−1 bands are assigned, respectively, to ν 8a, ν 19a and ν 19b vibration modes of coordinated Py-L, whereas the 1637 and 1540cm−1 bands correspond, respectively, to ν 8a and ν 19b vibration modes of [PyH]+. The band observed at about 1576cm−1 could be assigned to pyridine bonded to OH− groups on the surface support [37]. The area of the ν 19b band at 1450cm−1 is used to quantify the total amount of Lewis acid sites and the area of the 1540cm−1 band for the amount of Brønsted acid sites, using their molar adsorption coefficients that are ɛ =1.13cmμmol−1 and ɛ =1.28cmμmol−1, respectively [38]. The results are reported in Table 2 . For the γ-Al2O3 support, only bands assigned to coordinated pyridine on Lewis acid sites were observed. This is an expected result since alumina does not present OH groups strong enough to protonate the pyridine. In accordance with the literature, the addition of Mo causes the Lewis acidity to decrease and the Brønsted acidity to increase [29,39]. In this work, the Brønsted acidity appears at ≥7wt% Mo, coinciding with the appearance of Al2(MoO4)3 phase. Since crystalline MoO3 does not lead to significant generation of Brønsted acidity [34], it can be inferred that Al2(MoO4)3 could be responsible for the increase in Brønsted acidity. Rajagopal et al. [39] have proposed that the Brønsted acid sites, which are generated with Mo loading, are associated with tetrahedral molybdenum species strongly bound in a monodentate manner to Al in the support or to Mo in polymolybdate layer. Wang et al. [30] have reported that Al2(MoO4)3 phase, similar to the tetrahedrally coordinated Mo6+ (T), is also tetrahedrally coordinated. They have shown that tetrahedrally coordinated Mo6+ in molybdena–alumina catalysts could be the active catalytic site for syngas methanation [30]. In this work, it is then speculated that the Al2(MoO4)3 phase contributes to the formation of Brønsted acid sites by the way of Mo6+ (T)–OH species [29]. Based on this speculation, the lower amount of Brønsted acid sites for 9MoAl (Table 2, entry 6) could result from the observed interaction between Al2(MoO4)3 and MoO3, which disturb the formation of Mo–OH acid sites. 3.2 Biginelli reaction The catalytic performances of the samples were evaluated in the Biginelli reaction with a ratio of 2:2:3 of benzaldehyde, ethyl acetoacetate, and urea, respectively, to obtain 5-ethoxycarbonyl-4-phenyl-6-methyl-3,4-dihydropyridin-2(1H)-one known by the DHPM acronym. The reaction was performed under solvent free conditions. The results are summarized in Table 2. Biginelli reaction in the absence of catalyst (Table 2, entry 1) or in presence of bare γ-Al2O3 support (Table 2, entry 2) was found to be very slow and gave a poor yield of DHPM (8% isolated) after a longer reaction time (10h). The presence of molybdenum is required to promote the reaction. The yield of DHPM strongly increases with the Mo content, reaching a maximum for 7MoAl before slightly decreasing (Table 2, Fig. 8 ). Thus, the yield of DHPM reached a maximum of 82% for 7MoAl after 1h of reaction (Table 2, entry 5). This is an encouraging result for a one-step synthesis carried out under solvent free conditions. Nevertheless, the isolated yield of 98% reported by Jain et al. [25] could not be reached. They have used a 16wt% MoO3/Al2O3 (i.e., 10.7wt% Mo/Al2O3) catalyst prepared by wet impregnation and calcined at 550°C for 6h. Their better catalytic performance could result from the use of a different ratio of benzaldehyde, ethyl acetoacetate, and urea. The ratio was 1:1:1 versus 2:2:3 in our work. Catalytic results show a clear dependence on the molybdenum content. In Fig. 8 the evolution of the DHPM yield, obtained during Biginelli reaction, and the amount of Brønsted acid sites of the catalytic materials, obtained by FTIR of adsorbed pyridine, are represented as a function of the Mo content for all the samples. The DHPM yield and the amount of Brønsted acid sites evolve similarly with Mo content of the catalysts, which suggests that Brønsted acid sites are involved in the Biginelli condensation and promote the formation of DHPM. The 12MoAl shows a lower DHPM yield (72%) than 7MoAl (82%) despite the similar amount of Brønsted acid sites (26μmolg−1) (Table 2, entries 7 and 5, respectively). This behavior can be attributed to the increase in Al2(MoO4)3 particle size, which induces that a portion of the active sites is less accessible for the molecules to react. The results stated above showed that the best DHPM yield was obtained for 7MoAl. Therefore, the effect of catalyst concentration, reaction temperature and reusability were examined for this sample. To evaluate the influence of the amount of catalyst, Biginelli reaction was carried out with 0.1g and 0.3g instead of 0.2g. The resulting DHPM yields were 28% and 80% (Table 2, entries 8 and 9), respectively, showing that the optimum amount of catalyst is 0.2g (isolated yield 82%). The use of higher amount (0.3g) did not improve the yield (80%). To examine the effect of the temperature, the reaction was performed at different temperatures. In our operating conditions, after 1h reaction time, the best DHPM yield (82%) was obtained at 100°C versus 80°C reported by Jain et al. [25]. At room temperature the reaction was slow and gave a yield of 35%. The increase of temperature to 120°C did not improve the DHPM yield (81%). The reusability of 7MoAl was investigated under optimal (and typical) operating conditions (0.2g catalyst, reaction temperature 100°C, reaction time 1h). Used 7MoAl sample was recovered by filtration, washed with ultra-pure water, dried overnight at 100°C and reused in the next runs without further purification. DHPM yield is given in Fig. 9 for each run. The three consecutive runs give similar yield as the fresh one (run 1). Moreover, the molybdenum content of the recovered catalyst has been quantified by ICP. The Mo loading remained the same after 4 runs, no leaching of Mo was observed that is in accordance with the literature [25]. Mo/γ-Al2O3 appears to be a highly recyclable catalyst for the Biginelli reaction. Physical data for 5-ethoxycarbonyl-4-phenyl-6-methyl-3,4-dihydropyridin-2(1H)-one. Mp 200–203°C (Lit 202–204°C [25]). IR (KBr): ν max =3247, 3118, 1727, 1721, 1704, 1649, 1472, 1224, 1096cm−1. 1H NMR (400MHz, DMSO-d 6 ): δ =9.21 (s, 1H, NH), 7.76 (s, 1H, NH), 7.26 (s, 5H, C6H5), 5.14 (s, 1H, J =2.87Hz, CH), 4.0 (q, J =6.5Hz, 2H, OCH2CH3), 2.51 (s, 3H, CH3), 1.11 (t, J =6.5Hz, 3H, OCH2CH3) ppm. 13C NMR (100MHz, DMSO-d 6 ): δ =165.4 (COOEt), 152.2 (C2), 148.4 (C6), [144.9, 128.5, 127.3, 126.3]C arom, 99.3 (C5), 59.2 (OCH2CH3), 54 (C4), 17.8 (CH3), 14.1 (OCH2CH3) ppm. 4 Conclusion Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different metal loadings were prepared by wet impregnation method and tested for the Biginelli reaction under solvent free conditions. The DHPM yield goes through an optimum as a function of the molybdenum content, the best result being obtained for 7wt% Mo (isolated yield=82%). Alumina supported Mo catalysts appeared to be highly stable and reusable materials for this reaction. The existence of Al2(MoO4)3 phase on Mo/γ-Al2O3 samples was confirmed by X-ray diffraction and Fast Fourier Transform analysis. The catalyst characterization by FTIR of adsorbed pyridine would suggest a link between the presence of Al2(MoO4)3 phase and the existence of Brønsted acid sites, which appear to be involved in the Biginelli condensation and promote the formation of DHPM. Acknowledgements The authors acknowledge Frédéric Lecornué, Associate Professor at the University of Poitiers, for the 1H, 13C NMR analysis and also thank the Algerian Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research for the financial support. coredata.dc:description: Alumina supported Mo catalysts with varying metal loading (2–12wt%) were tested in the Biginelli reaction under solvent free conditions for synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2-(1H)-one (DHPM). The DHPM yield increased with Mo loading, going through a maximum for 7wt% Mo. Alumina supported Mo catalysts appeared to be highly stable and reusable materials for this reaction. A suite of characterization techniques that included X-ray diffraction, Fast Fourier Transform analysis and FTIR of adsorbed pyridine revealed that the DHPM formation is related to the existence of Brønsted acid sites that would be linked to the presence of Al2(MoO4)3 phase.
